Thanks to the lack of explanation you are also left in the dark as to what you should do to fix something, how to keep on sleeping until the bar is full (It interrupts at irregular intervals) and how much food you actually have. You will also notice a vicious cycle of I have no food -> I have no money to buy food -> I dig for money -> I need more food but I have no food -> I have no money to buy food and so on and so on and so on. The game contains some fun easter eggs here and there but without a real goal and seemingly effectless shops the game will bore you before you even started to like it. It's cheap, so if you really need to kill some time you might want this, but you're better off doing almost anything else.

[Review copy provided]Domestic Dog Simulator is, as you you may have guessed, a simulator game where you play as a dog. The game was developed by Surreal Distractions who maybe, just maybe, were inspired by another slightly related anti-game? But before I start to review this game, I would like to say that I am appreciative that I was able to have been given this game and though it may not overly appeal to me, some of you may genuinely enjoy it.Once you have hatched from your egg, you'll be wondering what the hell you are supposed to actually do. On the store page it does give a slight suggestion: Play, eat, drink, and sleep, remember to take care of yourself! But your first experience will be something more like this: Play, eat, drink, and sleep, remember to take care of yourself! ♥♥♥♥♥♥ oh sorry, urinate on everything. Once you have gotten bored from excreting your bodily fluids and getting hit by cars, you might like to try playing with a ball. Yep, that was fun for about 2 seconds. You are able to customise your house in this game and your dog which may appeal to you, but other than that all you can really do in the game is summed up in the "joke reviews" which are actually entirely serious. Here are a couple:Originally posted by (CHOPPAH) frankly:Recommended0.1 hrs on recordPosted: 14 SeptemberI spent 10 minutes peeing on everything, got confused, and turned the game off. 10/10 would recommend.Originally posted by Sticky Nut Juice:Recommended0.6 hrs on recordPosted: 21 SeptemberI pee'd on some stuff, got fleas, and played arcade games fun for a an hour or twoThe pixel graphics are very colourful and may be appealing for some to look at. Recieving a new dog with green hair and black lines across it is always interesting to see. Even though the game lacks in most other areas, it does give a certain seductive charm with its vibrant appearance.A question I asked myself when playing was, is it funny? You can urinate on almost everything and even eat your own poop, but that slight chuckle in your mind tends to wear off after the first 10 minutes of playing.There is some music in the game. It's quite emotionally gripping. Not really, it actually gets quite droning after a while but atleast it's not completely silent.Entertainment-As you will have probably gotten the impression from my points before, the game isn't overly entertaining and really doesn't entice me to go and play it some more. It is repetitive and is the type of game that you would only drop in to play for 2 minutes.Summary Pros+Is enjoyable to discover the different things for the first time+Customisation of your dog/house+Trading cards+GraphicsNeutral+/-Music is okay, but tends to drone on a bitCons-After discovering most of the features of the game it becomes quite repetitive-Doesn't give you any sort of direction or objective (no tutorial)-The humour wears off after 10 minutes-Isn't very entertainingConclusionDomestic Dog Simulator was certainly not the worst game I have ever played. There are plenty of games worse than this that exceed $3 and get up to $50+. This game will not be enjoyed by everyone, but if you do think that you would actually enjoy this game then maybe get it on sale and see what you think.5.5/10Liked that review? I have others!

												This game taught me even in this day and age of Steam Greenlight, that I shouldn't judge a book by it's cover.At first glance, this game looks like the same godawful joke games that are a dime-a-dozen these days around these parts. When you start to peel away the layers though, you find a pleasantly surprising time managment sim game. Your dog needs to poop, sleep, and eat. It's up to you to go out into the world and figure out the best way to get these objectives completed.You need to dig for cash to buy food, toys, collars, and other accessories for your home. There are arcade games to spend your money on, but I'd suggest making sure you have a full food dish first.You can't spend all day outside. This pup needs sleep. Your energy will deplete as you're out and about, so you need to wisely expend energy and take naps regularly.For the asking price, there is a welcome amount of depth here.

												Video games have a long history with capitalism. We’re used to scavenging garbage and loot for the merchant in town, playing our part in the endless recycling of items into cash which usually serves as the point for which the rest of the game rotates (especially if it happens to have a strong multiplayer focus). Sometimes we take up the role of the vender ourselves, be it in a higher management position (most city building sims) or direct transactions (Recettear), building our own economy by exploiting the nondescript customers who seem to exist solely to patronize our shop. There isn't anything particularly novel then about a game hinged around mass consumerism, but where Domestic Dog Simulator fails most is in masking or even pretending to recognize the economic loops providing it a skeleton of purpose, or hav ing anything interesting to say or do with them.You might imagine a game with as bland and direct a title as Domestic Dog Simulator would at the least be what it says on the tin, but aside from allowing you to take part in a handful of stereotypically doggy things (ie.♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on everything) there isn’t much that seems designed to imitate canine life. Maybe that’s because you aren’t actually playing as a dog, instead being presented with an egg which then hatches into disturbing robotic and Lovecraftian abominations, as if they were meant to encompass the entire animal kingdom by pulling bits and pieces from species that should never be mixed.And then you’re let loose into a town of shops and minor distractions. What exactly you’re meant to do from this point on is difficult to discern, but judging by the price tags affixed to every wall and object it seems clear you’ve been dropped into something of a consumer’s paradise. There are so many TVs upon which nothing plays, so many bizarre pieces of art to hang in your empty home. Vending machines sit on every corner ready to dispense a beverage at the push of a button, or perhaps you’d prefer the unmanned cafe, coffees waiting for you on the counter.There is so much random stuff to buy in Domestic Dog Simulator, which is especially odd given there isn’t any clear way to make money to purchase any of it. Eventually I stumbled upon a random lot behind my house with a convenient sign telling me to “dig”, so obediently I began scratching at the ground and was soon rewarded with a bundle of cash that had inexplicably been buried here. “Good” the game seemed to be saying to me, “now run off to one of the shops and pick out something nice.”This, it would seem, was the life I was intended to live. One of physical labor feeding into a desire to buy things I could do nothing with. There’s no real economy in Domestic Dog Simulator, you simply exist to consume, with the menial tasks required to obtain anything attempting to disguise how hideously pointless everything is. Perhaps then this could have served to illustrate the imaginary meaning used to justify unchecked consumption, but there is no attempt at critique, no commentary on the dangers of systemic capitalistic control or even a hint that the developer recognized what they were making. It just gives the player what it thinks they want, no frills attached, with a giant billboard of the developer’s other game, Squirreltopia, being the closest it comes to actually saying something about the world it has created. I suppose it still gets the last laugh though from everyone who bought it.You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

												Sometimes I wonder what developers think about when making a game that makes them go… “yeah, I’ll totally sell this game!” even if the price is under $4.Domestic Dog by Surreal Distractions is one such game. A dog-sim of sorts wanting to masquerade for something with actual substance (as I suppose most “something simulator” games are… ), you will be greeted with absolutely no tutorial and no idea of what the hell you’re supposed to do. Survive, I suppose. Basically you manage a dog that grows out of some sort of egg – the dog you get is random, and when you die, another one appears (not the same one, so you lose any “progress” made). You have food, water, dog money?, sleep – a few other stats to keep track of, basic stuff. You need to keep those up or you may pass out and/or die in the process. Tip of the day, in case it’s not obvious: You also have to mind cars, since they may run you over.What to do in the game? Well, be a dog, maybe? Eat, drink, poop, pee (sorry, I mean, ‘fire your weapon’) , bark at other dogs, eat said poo… you have a minuscule map, a shop with pointless things, and pretty much that’s it for the game. Boring doesn’t even begin to describe it. There is really nothing to salvage for me in this game: the graphics are terrible, pixelation has never looked so bad, and outdated (sorry, I mean, ‘retro’) bright colors are sure to blind you. Because we all know if we refer to a game as “retro” it automatically must forgive all design flaws. Yup!The UI feels cluttered and messy, everything seems to be moving, or too bright, or otherwise vying for your attention. The dogs themselves look rather ugly, even for alien dogs. To crown the beauty, the quite matching but horrifying 8-bit styled music and sounds effects (which are really loud, by the way!) are hideous. There is no semblance of a menu that I could see, thus I could find no way to lower the volume, and quite frankly I didn’t even bother to look beyond the esc key, I just muted everything while I played.If you enjoyed this then that's great, but it was absolutely NOT the game for me.So, would I recommend this? Sorry, but no. Steer clear.

												It's okay. Domestic Dog Simulator and Goat Simulator are the only two faux-Simulator games I know of that are worth anything.DDS has the potential to be fun. There are several different diversions and things to do. Randomly generated dogs and certain areas keep things interesting enough. There's something strangely hypnotic about it. The dogs require a gratuitous amount of maintaining their stats (Hunger, Thirst, Poop, etc.) but you only need to have the majority of them in good standing; you can go without food and happiness for long periods of time so long as you continue to drink, sleep and be fit. There's an EKG beside your stats that will fluctuate - will beep when you're in mortal danger.At times the controls that require tap-tap-tapping of WASD can put you in danger when you wouldn't think you should be (lasers in the warehouse have a much bigger hit radius than it'd seem) - standard complaint with most of those pixel-side-scrolling-things. Once you've make made the rounds a few times, the world suddenly feels empty. There are no sound options and the windowed mode is laughable (requires a magnifying glass). I enjoy playing DDS (thus far - unsure of how long that'll last), so I record this as a Positive Recommendation. I implore potential buyers to read the negative reviews; seems the positive reviews are full of headache-inducing "jokes" - the negative reviews (other'n the raging ones) are much more relevant to those who want to know what's what.Domestic Dog Simulator IS another one of "those" "Simulator" games, but it's acceptable, (>)decent(?) even.
